title: Alex Parker
text:
Alexander Hershaw Parker (2 August 1935 – 7 January 2010) was a Scottish <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and manager. Parker played for <a href="Falkirk%20F.C.">Falkirk</a>, <a href="Everton%20F.C.">Everton</a> and <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a>, amongst others. Parker was named in Falkirk's "Team of the Millennium" and Everton's Hall of Fame.
Playing career.
Falkirk.
Parker, a fullback, began his career with <a href="Kello%20Rovers%20F.C.">Kello Rovers</a>, turning semi-professional when he joined <a href="Falkirk%20F.C.">Falkirk</a> in 1952. The highlight of Parker's time with the "Bairns" was their <a href="1956%E2%80%9357%20Scottish%20Cup">1957</a> <a href="Scottish%20Cup">Scottish Cup</a> victory, as they defeated <a href="Kilmarnock%20F.C.">Kilmarnock</a> in a replayed final.
Everton.
Parker moved to <a href="Merseyside">Merseyside</a> in June 1958 when Everton paid £18,000 in a double signing of Parker and <a href="Eddie%20O%27Hara%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201935%29">Eddie O'Hara</a> both from Falkirk. Parker's "Toffees" debut was delayed by his requirement to fulfil National Service in <a href="Cyprus">Cyprus</a>. He eventually became a stalwart in the side which won the <a href="1962%E2%80%9363%20in%20English%20football">1962–63</a> <a href="List%20of%20English%20football%20champions">league championship</a>, finishing six points ahead of runners-up <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham</a>.
After this triumph, however, hamstring injuries started to trouble Parker, and he left <a href="Goodison%20Park">Goodison Park</a> in 1965.
Southport.
He joined <a href="Southport%20F.C.">Southport</a> for £2,000. He stayed 3 years with the "Sandgrounders".
Ballymena United.
Parker next moved to Northern Ireland to become player-manager of <a href="Ballymena%20United%20F.C.">Ballymena United</a>.
Drumcondra.
He signed for <a href="Drumcondra%20F.C.">Drumcondra F.C.</a> in December 1969 and made his <a href="League%20of%20Ireland">League of Ireland</a> debut at <a href="Tolka%20Park">Tolka Park</a> on 4 January 1970 in a 3–1 defeat to Dundalk. He left for after only three months to return to the UK.
International.
Parker gained his first <a href="cap%20%28football%29">cap</a> for <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a> against <a href="Portugal%20national%20football%20team">Portugal</a> in 1955 while playing for Falkirk. He was selected in the squad for the <a href="1958%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1958 FIFA World Cup</a>, making one appearance against <a href="Paraguay%20national%20football%20team">Paraguay</a>. This also transpired to be his final national team cap, which some regarded as "perverse"; former teammate <a href="Alex%20Young%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201937%29">Alex Young</a> stated that Parker was still the best player in his position in Britain. Parker also represented the <a href="Scottish%20League%20XI">Scottish League XI</a>.
Southport manager.
Parker returned to Souhtport where he was given a coaching role. Two months later he was promoted to manager but this appointment lasted only a single season.
After football.
After his retirement from the footballing world, Parker became a <a href="public%20house">publican</a> in <a href="Runcorn">Runcorn</a>. He then lived in <a href="Gretna%2C%20Scotland">Gretna</a>, Dumfriesshire.
Parker died of a heart attack on 7 January 2010.
